xxl.cursors
Class DecoratorCursor

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.DecoratorCursor
Direct Known Subclasses:
Dropper, Filter, MultiMapper, Remover, Taker, TempCursor, UnmodifiableCursor
public class DecoratorCursor
extends Object
implements Cursor

This class decorates a Cursor passing by all its method calls.
It realizes a design pattern, named Decorator.

Intent:
"Attach additional responsibilities to an object dynamically. Decorators provide a flexible alternative to subclassing for extending functionality."
For further information see: "Gamma et al.: DesignPatterns. Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software. Addision Wesley 1998."

Note: The given Iterator is wrapped to a Cursor.

The usage of this class can be seen for example in the following classes:

  • Filter
  • Dropper
  • Taker
  • Remover

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor

Field Detail

cursor

protected Cursor cursor
The internal used cursor.
Constructor Detail

DecoratorCursor

public DecoratorCursor(Iterator iterator)
Creates a new DecoratorCursor. Wraps the given iterator to a cursor by passing by all method calls to it.
Parameters:
iterator - The iterator to be decorated.
Method Detail

close

public void close()
Closes the DecoratorCursor. Signals the DecoratorCursor to cleanup resources, close files, etc. After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results.

Multiple calls to close() do not have any effect, i.e. if close() was called the DecoratorCursor remains in the state "closed".
Calls cursor.close().
Specified by:
close in interface Cursor

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
Calls cursor.hasNext().
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the DecoratorCursor has more elements.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration.
This element will be removed from the underlying collection, if next is called.
Calls cursor.next().
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection. (optional operation)
Calls cursor.peek().
Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by the input-Cursor.

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the DecoratorCursor. (optional operation)
Calls cursor.remove().
This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. The behavior of a DecoratorCursor is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the input-Cursor.
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the DecoratorCursor to its initial state. (optional operation)
That means the reset method of the input-Cursor is called.
So the caller is able to traverse the underlying collection again. The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying collection, are still persistent.
Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the input-Cursor.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek-operation is supported by this DecoratorCursor.
That means cursor.supportsPeek() is called and the result is true if the input-Cursor supports the peek-operation. Else returns false.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this DecoratorCursor.

update

public void update(Object object)
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Replaces the object that was returned by the last call to next or peek. (optional operation)
This operation must not be called after a call to hasNext. It should follow a call to next or peek. This method should be called only once per call to next or peek.
The behavior of a DecoratorCursor is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
The update method of the input-Cursor is called.
Specified by:
update in interface Cursor
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the object returned by the last call to next or peek.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if there is no object which can be updated.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the input-Cursor.
